title: U.S. Officials Get Approval to Travel for China Plane Crash Probe; National Transportation Safety Board investigators hope to leave for China this week
text:
While China is leading the investigation, under international-aviation rules, U.S. representatives are allowed to participate in part because the plane involved in the crash—a Boeing 737-800—was made in the U.S.

It wasn't immediately clear when the U.S. team would depart, but the safety board said it hopes the team will leave this week. The NTSB has already appointed a senior official to lead its team and has been in touch with the Chinese investigator-in-charge, a spokesman said earlier.

The crash on March 21 of the China Eastern plane caused it to disintegrate when it nosedived into a mountain in southern China, scattering debris across a wide area of heavily wooded and rugged terrain.

On Sunday, a team of firefighters found the aircraft's flight-data recorder buried several feet underground roughly 130 feet from where the plane crashed in southern China's Guangxi autonomous region, officials said. That device, along with a cockpit-voice recorder that search teams found last week, should help investigators determine why the aircraft crashed, flight-safety experts have said.

Flight-data recorders track details about flights, including airspeed and the position of the wing flaps. Cockpit-voice recorders typically keep a rolling two-hour record of the sounds in the cockpit. In addition to the recorders, investigators have said more than 33,000 pieces of debris from the crash have been found.

Overseas travelers entering China are required to quarantine themselves for at least two weeks, with many cities adopting an additional period of a week or longer of isolation at home or government facilities.

Investigators in China have said all 132 people on board the plane died, making it the country's worst air disaster since 1994.

Yoko Kubota contributed to this article.
